channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: I.C.C. Issues Arrest Warrants for Netanyahu and Gallant
item.description: The International Criminal Court rejected Israel’s challenges to its jurisdiction, and also issued a warrant for a top Hamas official. Its chief prosecutor had sought the arrests for war crimes in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israel and Iran Seemed on the Brink of a Bigger War. What’s Holding Them Back?
item.description: So far, direct attacks between the two adversaries have been precise and calculated. Whether that lasts is another question.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: People stand near the remains of a missile near the Dead Sea, in Israel, in October.

item.title: Abused Workers in India’s Sugar Industry Face Worse Fates if They Quit
item.description: Why would anyone stay in a job where abuse is rampant and women are coerced into hysterectomies? Because the cost of escaping India’s cane fields is often even higher.
item.dc:creator: Qadri Inzamam, Megha Rajagopalan and Saumya Khandelwal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prahlad Pawar, 34, right, with his wife, Pushpa Pawar, 31, in Kolgaon, western India. The Pawars say their employer made them work as his personal servants in the off-season. They eventually escaped, hiking for days back to their village.

item.title: Israel Strikes Near Beirut as U.S. Envoy Pushes Ahead on Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, was in Israel and planned to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, seeking a truce in the country’s war with the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising after an Israeli airstrike on the Dahiya, south of Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Gifts Bears and a Lion to North Korea
item.description: Vladimir Putin also presented a lion to Pyongyang Zoo, one of the more than 70 animals he sent as an emblem of the deepening friendship between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A lion at the Pyongyang Zoo in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Wednesday, after being transferred from the Moscow Zoo, in a handout photo from Russia’s natural resources ministry.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Struck It With New Missile; ICBM Claim Is Disputed
item.description: Russia struck the city of Dnipro with a volley that Ukraine said included an intercontinental ballistic missile. Western officials said an ICBM was not used.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in eastern Ukraine last week.

item.title: John Prescott, Former UK Deputy Prime Minister, Dies at 86
item.description: Mr. Prescott was a waiter on cruise ships before rising through the trade union movement and entering politics. He became one of the country’s best-known politicians under Tony Blair.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Michael Crabtree/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: John Prescott in London in 1998.

item.title: Why Mexico Isn’t Panicking About Another Trump Presidency
item.description: Mexico is banking on its ability to negotiate with a deal maker like Donald J. Trump, and many officials say the country is better prepared and has more leverage than it did during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump speaks during a meeting of the House of Representatives G.O.P. Conference at the Hyatt Regency in Washington, on Nov. 13.

item.title: Canada Prepares for Immigration Surge After Trump Vows Mass Deportation
item.description: The Canadian authorities are preparing for a possible spike in undocumented migrants, just as Trump appointees complain about too many people arriving from Canada.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants who had crossed the border from Canada, many of them from India, talking to taxi drivers in Plattsburgh, N.Y., who were offering rides to New York City.

item.title: Should Olaf Scholz Step Aside in the New Race for German Chancellor?
item.description: Increasing numbers in his own center-left party say he should, arguing for a more charismatic leader who might better their electoral chances.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, left, with Boris Pistorius, the country’s defense minister, during a session of Parliament earlier this month in Berlin.

item.title: Bathing in Oil at a Climate Summit? It Leaves a Stain.
item.description: In Azerbaijan, site of the COP29 climate talks and a petrostate, people aren’t only proud of their oil. They swear by its health benefits and visit resorts to soak in it.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: People from across the former Soviet Union flock to the health resorts in Naftalan, Azerbaijan, to bathe in the area’s oil.

item.title: Russia Intensifies Assaults on an Exhausted Ukraine
item.description: Overextended Ukrainian forces lack manpower and artillery against Russian forces willing to absorb staggering casualties.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Vatican Sets Out New Rules to Simplify Papal Funerals
item.description: Pope Francis’s down-to-earth style has become a trademark of his papacy. New rules for papal burials are another step to seal it into his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Pope Francis during the funeral of Pope Benedict XVI last year. From the beginning of his papacy, Francis has used symbols to break from the formality and pomp that has long marked the Roman Catholic Church.

item.title: U.S. and Europeans Move to Censure Iran for Nuclear Secrecy
item.description: Before Donald J. Trump takes office, the West wants to call out Iran for failing to adhere to treaty obligations to be transparent about its nuclear past and present.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr, Iran, in April.

item.title: Who Has the ICC Charged With War Crimes?
item.description: The short list includes Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the deposed president of Sudan, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, with Maria Lvova-Belova, also subject to an I.C.C. arrest warrant, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: ICC Had Sought Warrants for 3 Hamas Leaders. At Least 2 Are Now Dead.
item.description: Karim Khan had asked the court to issue warrants for Hamas’s top leader in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar; its political leader, Ismail Haniyeh; and its military chief, Muhammad Deif.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: The court’s chief prosecutor initially sought arrest warrants for three Hamas leaders. From left to right: Ismail Haniyeh, Muhammad Deif and Yahya Sinwar.

item.title: Deaths of at Least 4 Tourists in Laos Raise Alarm About Tainted Drinks
item.description: Travelers from the United States, Australia and Denmark have died in the Southeast Asian nation in recent days. Officials warned of poisoning caused by alcoholic drinks containing methanol.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: At a bar in Vang Vieng, Laos, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Forced Labor and Hysterectomies Are Darkly Linked in India
item.description: Our correspondent explains how an exploitative labor system has produced a system of brutality in the country’s sugar fields.
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pushpa Pawar, 31, standing with relatives in the village of Kolgaon, India. Ms. Pawar’s husband, Prahlad Pawar, a cane cutter, said that the couple and their children had been detained by a contractor and forced to work as servants.

item.title: COP29 Climate Talks in Baku, Azerbaijan, Are Teetering
item.description: Western countries are confronting demands for trillions of dollars to fight climate change and to cope with its worsening effects.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The Chinese delegation pavilion in Baku, Azerbaijan. Newly industrialized countries like China and India are part of an effort to secure trillions in climate financing.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Gaetz appeared with Senator JD Vance in Washington.

item.title: Accusations of “Race-Shifting” Prompt Canadian Cabinet Minister to Resign
item.description: Randy Boissonnault, who resigned as employment minister, had long described himself as the great-grandson of a Cree woman, but now acknowledges he was wrong about his family’s ancestry.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Randy Boissonnault stepped down as Canada’s employment minister on Wednesday, dealing another blow to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

item.title: Democrats Split as Senate Rejects Bills to Block Weapons Transfers to Israel
item.description: The legislation failed resoundingly but highlighted a growing Democratic divide over whether the United States should withhold some weapons to register its disapproval of Israel’s war tactics.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: People running toward humanitarian aid packages dropped over the northern Gaza Strip in April.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Inside Russia With U.S. Missiles
item.description: The next two or three months in Ukraine are likely to be exceedingly violent, in a war that has already been the deadliest in Europe in the past 80 years. Marc Santora, who has been reporting from Ukraine since the beginning of the war with Russia, explains why.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Nikolay Nikolov, James Surdam and Laura Salaberry
item.media:credit: A. J. Mast for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Anti-Personnel Mines for Ukraine
item.description: Plus, Daniel Craig’s performance in “Queer.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier outside Toretsk, in October.

item.title: U.S. Casts Sole Vote Against Gaza Cease-Fire Resolution
item.description: The U.S. veto at the U.N. came as the Biden administration’s envoy in Lebanon reported “additional progress” on cease-fire talks in the war between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Euan Ward and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Robert A. Wood, the American ambassador to the U.N., raising his hand to veto a draft resolution calling for a cease fire in Gaza, on Wednesday at UN headquarters in New York City.

item.title: What Are Anti-Personnel Mines?
item.description: The Biden administration has agreed to send the weapons to Ukraine, despite their reputation for killing and maiming civilians.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, John Ismay and Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An emergency services worker holds a sign warning that the nearby forest is mined as his colleague clears a path in Sosnove, Ukraine.

item.title: Is Trump More Flexible on China Than His Hawkish Cabinet Picks Suggest?
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is assembling a team of aides bent on confrontation with China. But he also has advisers who do business there, including Elon Musk.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Many top officials in China see the United States as a superpower in decline.

item.title: U.S. Vetoes Gaza Cease-Fire Resolution at U.N. Security Council
item.description: The United States, which has blocked four other resolutions, said it vetoed the most recent version because it did not make the release of hostages a precondition for a truce.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Robert A. Wood, the American ambassador to the U.N., raising his hand to veto a draft resolution calling for a cease fire in Gaza, on Wednesday at UN headquarters in New York City.

item.title: Ugandan Opposition Leader Charged After Being ‘Kidnapped’ in Kenya
item.description: Kizza Besigye, a former presidential candidate, went missing over the weekend as he visited the Kenyan capital, reappearing days later in military custody back in Uganda.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Kizza Besigye, left, and an associate, Haji Obeid Lutale, in the steel dock of the Uganda Military General Court in Kampala on Wednesday.

item.title: A Travel Writer Remembers Arthur Frommer
item.description: The creator of the popular guidebook series, who recently died, not only democratized travel, but supported sustainable travel, before it got that name.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:description: Arthur Frommer in Trafalgar Square in London in 1976.

item.title: Biden Agrees to Supply Ukraine With Anti-Personnel Mines
item.description: The decision is the latest in a series of moves by the U.S. and Russia that have escalated tensions between the two.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier outside Toretsk, in October. The Biden administration has approved supplying Ukraine with anti-personnel mines to bolster defenses against Russia’s increasing reliance on foot soldiers to lead their assaults.

item.title: Middle East Airlines Has Become an Unlikely National Hero in Lebanon
item.description: Middle East Airlines has managed to fly through regional and civil wars since the 1960s. And it is still in the skies today.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Middle East Airlines flight over the outskirts of Beirut last month.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Will Head to Israel, Citing Progress on Lebanon Cease-Fire
item.description: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, held a second day of talks in the Lebanese capital to seek a truce between Israel and Hezbollah. The militant group’s leader said peace now depended on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Amos Hochstein, center, a top U.S. envoy to the Middle East, was in Beirut, Lebanon, for talks on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Promises Clean Water. Will He Clean Up PFAS?
item.description: Public health advocates worry that Donald Trump could unravel federal clean water efforts, including restrictions on lead pipes and chemicals known as PFAS.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Erin Hooley/Chicago Tribune/Tribune News Service, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A geologist collected samples of treated Lake Michigan water in a laboratory in Illinois in 2021 that were found to have PFAS contamination.

item.title: What Trump’s Return Could Mean for Animals
item.description: A second Trump administration could alter the lives of all sorts of animals, whether they live in laboratories, zoos, fields or forests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Catrin Einhorn
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.media:description: Caribous graze near ConocoPhillips oil pipelines on the North Slope of Alaska. During his first term, President Trump moved to open up the state’s Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas development.

item.title: Long Tied to Russia, Georgia’s Winemakers Look to the West
item.description: Some vintners in the former Soviet republic are seeking to break a politically risky dependence on Russia and focus more on high-value European and American markets.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The wine harvest in Georgia’s Kakheti region in October. Wine has been cultivated continuously in Georgia for more than 8,000 years.

item.title: U.S. Pauses Operations at Kyiv Embassy, Warning of ‘Significant Air Attack’
item.description: The unusual alert came a day after Ukraine used American-made ballistic missiles to strike Russian territory for the first time. At least two other Western embassies closed for the day after the warning.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Searchlights in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, early Wednesday.

item.title: Smog in Pakistan Smothers Lahore, Breaking a Vibrant City’s Rhythms
item.description: Lahore comes alive at night. But this year’s record onslaught of cold-weather smog — residents call it the “fifth season” — has broken its rhythms.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Betsy Joles
item.media:description: Full weekend lockdowns, reminiscent of Covid-19 restrictions, are being imposed in Lahore, Pakistan, because of the intense air pollution.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The 1,000th day of war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: John Hamilton/White Sands Missile Range, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A test of the Army Tactical Missile System, known as ATACMS.

item.title: Hong Kong Media Mogul Jimmy Lai Takes Stand in National Security Trial
item.description: Jimmy Lai, who is charged with national security offenses, testified that his newspaper “carried a torch to the reality” of people’s desire for freedom in the city.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Tiffany May
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai in Hong Kong in 2019. He has long been one of Hong Kong’s most vocal critics of China’s ruling Communist Party.

item.title: Iran Suggests Pausing High Levels of Uranium Enrichment to Avoid Censure, Monitor Says
item.description: Iran has raised the possibility it would stop expanding its stockpile of uranium enriched to a purity of 60 percent — very close to the level needed for a weapon, the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog says.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Mehr News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A reactor building at the Bushehr nuclear power plant just outside the southern city of Bushehr, Iran, in 2010.

item.title: Activist Kianoosh Sanjari’s Final Act Stuns Iran
item.description: Repeatedly imprisoned in his country, Kianoosh Sanjari refused to be silenced by the government. But in the end, despairing of change, he silenced himself.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Kianoosh Sanjari speaking at an Amnesty International concert in New York in 2014.

item.title: Netanyahu Offers $5 Million for Each Hostage Freed in Gaza
item.description: As he resists pressure to reach a cease-fire that would release the captives, Israel’s prime minister is now offering a reward for their freedom, while still vowing to punish anyone who hurts a hostage.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has offered a $5 million reward and safe passage out of Gaza to anyone who returns an Israeli captive held in the enclave.

item.title: Biden Fades Out of the Picture in Talks With World Leaders
item.description: As he made his final appearance at global gatherings, including at the Group of 20 summit in Brazil, President Biden lobbied for his foreign policy goals even as leaders shifted attention away from him.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden and Brazil’s president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, met on Tuesday during a working lunch at the Group of 20 summit in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine hits Russia with U.S. Missiles
item.description: Plus, the Scandinavian band that’s big in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: John Hamilton/White Sands Missile Range, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The U.S.-made Army Tactical Missile System, known as ATACMS.

item.title: Son of Norway’s Crown Princess Is Arrested on Suspicion of Rape
item.description: Marius Borg Hoiby, the stepson of Crown Prince Haakon of Norway, was arrested on Monday. His lawyer denied the accusation and said his client was cooperating with the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Marius Borg Hoiby in 2022. He was 4 when his mother, Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway, married Crown Prince Haakon in 2001.

item.title: Sweden, Finland and Norway Update Crisis Advice as Ukraine-Russia War Grinds On
item.description: Sweden, Finland and Norway have recently updated their advice for citizens preparing to survive war and other crises, wary of Ukraine’s grinding fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson, Johanna Lemola, Henrik Pryser Libell and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Soldiers in a military camp near Heinujarvi, in northern Finland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Brazilian Police Arrest Soldiers in Alleged Plot to Kill President Lula
item.description: Members of an elite army unit planned to kill Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in 2022 as part of an effort to keep Jair Bolsonaro in power after he lost the presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil defeated Jair Bolsonaro in a close election in 2022.

item.title: The Perfect Novel for the Baku Climate Summit: Lydia Kiesling’s Mobility
item.description: The U.N. climate conference, held in a petrostate, is a surreal moment. This darkly funny novel about Baku, oil companies and climate change in the first Trump term helps make sense of it all.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil fields on the outskirts of Baku, Azerbaijan, in view of the stadium, left, where the U.N. climate summit is taking place.

item.title: Delhi Trudges Through Another Air Pollution Nightmare
item.description: The government seems powerless to protect its citizens from this annual crisis, let alone prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: India Gate in New Delhi was enveloped with smog on Tuesday.

item.title: As Pelicot Rape Trial Nears End in France, Wife Speaks of ‘Banality’
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot made her final address to the court, calling the things her husband allegedly did to her “unforgivable.”
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot entering the courthouse with her lawyers Stephane Babonneau, center, and Antoine Camus in Avignon, France, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine Fired U.S.-Made Missiles Into Russia for First Time, Officials Say
item.description: The attack came just days after President Biden gave Ukraine permission to use the weapons to strike targets inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: John Hamilton/White Sands Missile Range, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Biden on Sunday gave Ukraine authorization to use the U.S.-made Army Tactical Missile System, known as ATACMS, to strike inside Russia.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Visits Lebanon, Seeking Truce Between Israel and Hezbollah
item.description: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, said an end to the fighting was “within our grasp” after meeting in Beirut with Lebanon’s Parliament speaker, a key interlocutor with Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Adam Rasgon and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Damage at the site of an Israeli strike in the Zuqaq al-Blat neighborhood of Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin Lowers Nuclear Weapons Threshold After U.S. Allows Ukraine to Use Missiles Against Russia
item.description: A decree signed by the Russian leader, though long planned, came days after President Biden authorized the use of U.S.-supplied missiles by Ukraine for strikes inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin in Sochi, Russia, this month. His decree on nuclear weapons seemed timed to show that the Kremlin could respond aggressively to Ukrainian strikes with American missiles.

item.title: U.K. Farmers Protest in London Over Inheritance Tax Change
item.description: Farms worth more than about $1.3 million will face an estate tax from 2026, ending a previous exemption and prompting anger in some rural communities.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Tractors drove past Britain’s Parliament on Tuesday morning, as part of a broader protest by some farmers.

item.title: Man Drives Car Into Crowd Outside Primary School in China
item.description: The incident followed an attack by a driver last week that left 35 people dead, and a mass stabbing several days later.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Social Media, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Magicians Mount Search for Woman Behind Decades-Old Deception
item.description: A British society of magicians expelled a woman for tricking her way into the club in 1991. Now it wants to invite her back, but the woman seems to have pulled a disappearing act.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Neil Munns/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Magic Circle, a society of magicians, expelled a woman who had posed as a man to gain membership. Now the society is trying to track her down.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine’s new military powers.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading toward the Kursk region of Russia.

item.title: Why Michael Learns to Rock Is Big in Asia
item.description: Michael Learns to Rock hoped for success west of their native Denmark. But for 30 years, they’ve had a devoted following on the other side of the world.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times

item.title: Is the Russian Army Depleted From Fighting in Ukraine?
item.description: Researchers and journalists have found innovative ways to measure Russia’s ability to keep fighting.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cemetery for fallen Russian soldiers in Ulan-Ude, Russia, last year.
